text: tens of thousands of British citizens
are stranded around the world as a
result of the corona virus pandemic with
countries closing borders and
restricting the movement of people the
Foreign Secretary Dominic Robb has
announced plans to bring them home but
says the UK hasn't faced a challenge on
this scale in recent memory the
government will spend 75 million pounds
on a rescue mission including chartering
flights where no commercial ones are
available here's Caroline Hawley this is
one of the Rescue planes sent to Peru to
bring stranded British tourists home by
the end of tomorrow with specially
chartered flights the government hopes
to have about a thousand people back on
UK soil more such flights to other
countries will now follow look at the
smiles on these to junior doctors
they're heading home from a public
health research project in Peru to
rejoin the NHS and how much of a relief
is that going to be for you I think
there's been there's been a lot of
frustration from people in Peru that
there hasn't been so much communication
and things are taking a lot of time but
now things are happening I think
everyone's just very relieved in Lima no
space for social distancing as British
travellers queue up to get on the
flights Peru is in a state of emergency
and tourists have had to make long and
difficult journeys to the capital and
not everyone has made it we were sent
this footage by a British woman who'd
been staying at a hostel where others
were ill with coronavirus she's now been
taken out by the Peruvian authorities
disinfected and isolated in another
hotel they've just told us that if we
leave the hotel room at all that we'll
be arrested or the repatriation flights
that have gone we've unfortunately
missed and we're hoping now that the
embassy and Lima can obviously focus on
the situation in para one hostel and
obviously get all the British nationals
out safe and get us all home it's a week
since the Foreign Office advised all
British tourists abroad to head home and
this is the command center of a huge
global operation to help people come
back across oceans and continents
British tourists are
spirit to be repatriated and there's
been criticism of the Foreign Office for
not doing enough but the Foreign
Secretary says he's spoken to dozens of
his counterparts to urge them to keep
their airspace open and allow UK
citizens out commercial options are
still available don't wait don't run the
risk of getting stranded the airlines
are standing by to help you please book
your tickets as soon as possible where
commercial flights are no longer running
the government will provide the
necessary financial support for special
charter flights to bring UK nationals
back home from retired passengers on
cruise ships to young backpackers there
are hundreds of thousands of British
people stuck abroad right now the task
of bringing them home has no precedent
Caroline Hawley BBC news easyJet has
grounded its entire fleet as the
aviation industry struggles to cope with
the pandemic the budget airline said it
had made the move due to the
unprecedented travel restrictions
imposed by governments globally the
budget airline says its staff will be
paid under the government job retention
scheme right house the biggest
rent-to-own operator in the UK has
collapsed the business had been
struggling due to an influx of
compensation claims for selling to
people who couldn't pay right house says
customers should continue to make the
monthly payments required to keep their
household goods with administrators now
acting as the collecting agent Prince
Charles is out of self-isolation
following his diagnosis of coronavirus
the 71 year old Prince spent seven days
of isolating in Scotland after testing
positive and displaying mild symptoms
the Duchess of Cornwall tested negative
for the virus but will self isolate
until the end of the week Karuna virus
attacks your lungs with the sickest
patients needed to be put on ventilators
where a machine breathes for you the NHS
has 8,000 ventilators but predicts it
will need many more engineers at
University College London have been
working on a new breathing aid that
could mean fewer ventilators are
required and that could keep people out
of intensive care it's already been
approved for use and is now being tested
at four London hospitals at our medical
correspond
furgus Walsh explains for the very
sickest kovat 19 patients as in this
intensive care unit in Italy a
mechanical ventilator offers the best
chance of survival it takes over the job
of breathing giving the lungs a chance
to recover patients on ventilators need
to be sedated and they require expert
staff the NHS has around 8,000 of them
it's planning to acquire another 8,000
from suppliers in the coming weeks but
it's estimated up to 30,000 could be
needed at the peak of any outbreak here
this doctor spoke to us just after
coming off shift in intensive care and I
think it's encouraging that from the
government they've said that they would
try and find 30,000 ventilators I think
that it looks as if less than a third of
those might be available within the next
few weeks when I think this epidemic
will peak in the UK the government
admitted a communication confusion after
the UK failed to join in EU scheme to
source extra ventilators but denied the
NHS have been disadvantaged by contrast
this new device has been approved known
as continuous positive airway pressure
or CPAP they're already used in the NHS
but are in short supply so a team at
University College London working with
Mercedes Formula One devised a new one
normally medical device development
would take would take years and in this
instance we've been able to do it in
days University College London Hospital
which demonstrated the device is now
using it to treat patients with
coronavirus I sincerely think it may
actually save many lives by preventing
patients from needing to go on to a
ventilator and again saving that vital
resource for the very very severely ill
this is a great example of how the NHS
universities and industry are working
together at extraordinary pace to meet
the challenge posed by coronavirus if
the trials of this device go well then
Mercedes Formula One says it can produce
up to a thousand
these a day in Italy around half of Ko
bid 19 patients on CPAP did not need
intensive care so the new device could
greatly ease pressure on the NHS Fergus
watch BBC news
